Hi Tim:
I don't know if I'm contacting you at the right place on your channel, but I have a question about a very serious matter that "could be" a very serious, dangerous, safety-concern situation at Boca Chica.

I know you have Elon's ear, so I'm trusting that if you consider my concern to be a possible dangerous matter for his consideration; or at least a matter that a ground or flight engineer/ground supervisor should possibly be aware of, that you would pass along the below message to the proper management team. - PS - I have also posted the below concerns at the NASASpaceflight channel as well. Thank you Tim, in advance.

To whom this should concern on the SpaceX team: A curious thought just entered my mind: I've looked at Boca Chica and the surrounding area from satellite photos, and it appears to be a very sandy place. Also, from many videos I've watched, I've additionally noticed it is also a very sandy place as well, with lots of seriously blowing sand. My question is this (and I'm sure this subject was probably already worked out a long time ago, but asking can sometimes prevent future disasters...): Have the issues of blowing sand build-up, and contamination between moving parts, been factored into the safety models?

I'm positive that Elon, one of the greatest engineers in the world, has had a handle on this for years... But just thought I'd ask...

EXAMPLES: If somebody possibly had called NASA before the Challenger launch and asked about the effects of freezing weather on the solid-booster o-rings; or if somebody had called and asked what would happen if a piece of foam material broke off the side of the main fuel tank and struck the orbiter, like the Columbia accident; perhaps we would still have 14 wonderful members of the NASA management team, making manned spaceflight that much safer (who knows, perhaps a few of them might have been working for SpaceX by now)!

I don't know if any of these questions I ask ever make it beyond the YouTube "miscellaneous comments" graveyard or not, but it would certainly be my sincere wish that this one would at least make it to a ground-supervisor at Boca Chica, if only just for safety's sake.

Once again Tim, if you think this might be "a thing", I trust you implicitly to pass it up the ladder to the correct team / team-supervisor.

God bless you, and keep riding high! (You'll get there eventually!)

Sincerely, Michael

Single stage to orbit: the ultimate Catch 22. Add fuel to get sufficient delta v then, because of the added fuel weight, you need a tank to put it in, then because of the tank, the weight increases beyond workable methods. So, you need to add yet more fuel to obtain sufficient delta v to get that incremental weight to LEO. Then, you have to start it all over because the weight/delta v equation cannot reach equality (with the thrust available in the engine package). NASA struggled with this for years and came to the conclusion that a 3- stage rocket (Saturn 5) combined with a lunar orbit rendezvous program was needed to get the Apollo package to the moon and back. Catch 22 at its finest !!!

I guess von Braun figured he could get it (SSTO) to work but if NASA tried it and there was an explosion of the Nova booster at launch, the entire launch complex would be destroyed!!!

Flare going out is not a big deal. Especially not when it is windy. The biggest reason they want to burn the methane is not because of the risk of explosion, but because pure methane is a very potent greenhouse gas. Much worse than co2. Therefore it is better to burn it before releasing it in the atmosphere.
the flare stack burns off the methane which is CH4 which is more toxic than C02 for the atmosphere hence why its there, also removes it from the ground to prevent any explosions

Dear Tim Dodd, I'm full of admiration, your analysis of all things rocket. Your enthusiasm is infectious.
One thing you're less than convincing about is your estimate of the existence of life elsewhere.
There are thousands of millions of planets around stars - that's one statistic you've set your 'proof upon that' there must be life elsewhere.
Have you considered the statistics against there being life anywhere, including here? They're infinitesimal - in other words impossible!
There has to be an intervention for life to exist - no man can create even the lowest form of life. You can bring together all the components of the body, but, cannot build a body without having a starting block - like growing new noses and ears - can be done, but you need life to start it - even if you could build a body you'd never put life in it - impossible.
So, there is no life out there and the only people who surmise there is are either being disingenuous, or suggest it to get funding to go and see.
I'm really excited about the prospects of going to the moon and Mars. It's a huge adventure, brave, focused and amazing!
